forum.name: Reflecting on Math Anxiety, Mindsets, and the Potential to Learn Mathematics
forum.intro:
Fostering positive mathematics identities involves creating instructional environments in which students can see themselves as competent, valued, and productive doers and learners of mathematics. Unfortunately, myths and messages that one is either a math person or not or that showing effort in math is a sign of being “stupid” are pervasive. Furthermore, many students, and adult learners in particular, have had difficult and even damaging experiences with mathematics.

Countering these myths and beliefs and fostering equitable and inclusive mathematics learning environments are key to unlocking learners’ mathematics learning potential. In the next few activities, you will be learning about growth and fixed mindsets, math anxiety, and new findings in brain science that upend old myths and beliefs. We then turn to how to create equitable classrooms to foster the development of positive mathematics identities.

  1. Read this article on math anxiety and mindset from Education Week: The Myth Fueling Math Anxiety.
  2. Watch this 5-minute video of Dr. Jo Boaler discussing recent evidence from brain science that all students can learn math to high levels (from youcubed at Stanford University).

    Brain Plasticity
  3. Reflect on the article and the video in the discussion forum below. Click ADD DISCUSSION TOPIC to add a post to the forum. Share your thinking about
    • your experiences and/or that of your students relating to math anxiety and belief in yourself as a math learner;
    • how your beliefs about math learning or that of others (e.g., teachers, parents) have shaped your perspectives on math teaching;
    • what you do in your teaching to help students approach mathematics productively and see themselves as competent learners of mathematics; and
    • anything else raised in the article you’d like to comment on.
